intro: Byrsonima oxyphylla, commonly known as the "Brazilian cherry" or "sangre de Cristo," is a tropical tree native to South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its large, heart-shaped leaves and showy, pink to red flowers. The fruit is a drupe with a thick, leathery outer layer and a sweet, edible pulp. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has traditional uses in local medicine. The plant thrives in warm, humid climates and is adapted to well-drained soils.
